metadata.titleEn: Product data set of 30 m human activity parameters in Qilian Mountain Area in 2020 (V2.0)
metadata.description: This data set includes 30 m cultivated land and construction land distribution products in Qilian Mountain Area in 2020. The product comes from the land cover classification product of 30 m in Qilian Mountain Area in 2020. The land cover classification products of 30m in 2020 areproduced using change detection method based on the land cover classification product of 2019 in Google Earth engine platform with the Landsat series data . The overall accuracy of the product is better than 85%. This product is a continuation of the human activity parameter product from 1985 to 2019，which also can be downloaded from this website.

background: Land-cover datasets are crucial for research on eco-hydrological processes and earth system modeling. Remote sensing has become widely used as a macro-observing system for land-cover mapping, which can substitute for plant functional type (PFT) as the baseline. Several moderate to fine resolution global land-cover datasets, which are presented in detail in Table I, based on different satellite sensors are available from different research groups. These land-cover datasets listed in Table I have large variability for three reasons: 1) the data quality and properties are different; 2) there is no standard approach for classifying continuous vegetation cover into discrete categories; and 3) they are not consistent with the Earth System Model’s (ESM) requirements, because the concept of PFT, whose traits represent a combination of spectral relationships, and climatic, ecological, and theoretical assumptions, used in ESMs cannot be mapped directly using remote-sensing land-cover datasets. In addition, the classification accuracies of land-cover datasets vary and are hardly suited for land-process modeling and applications at a river basin scale. The highest uncertainty in land-cover classification from optical remotely sensed imagery occurs most frequently between the cropland and grassland categories and in dryland systems among the shrub, grassland, and forest categories because of differences in the minimum threshold required for forest cover. For the HRB, most are distributed over an arid region, so the vegetation classification in the HRB based on current land-cover datasets would cause very large uncertainty and may cause great error or even the failure of eco-hydrological and land-process modeling.
research objective: In order to improve the accuracy of eco-hydrological and land-process modeling in the HRB, a comprehensive method for mapping monthly land cover with fine spatial resolution and more categories of crop/vegetation is developed by using multiple classifiers and multisource remotely sensed data with different spatio-temporal resolutions and spectral bands.
challenges: The highest uncertainty in land-cover classification from optical remotely sensed imagery occurs most frequently between the cropland and grassland categories and in dryland systems among the shrub, grassland, and forest categories because of differences in the minimum threshold required for forest cover. For the HRB, most are distributed over an arid region, so the vegetation classification in the HRB based on current land-cover datasets would cause very large uncertainty and may cause great error or even the failure of eco-hydrological and land-process modeling.
methods: A mosaic of the HRB is made using Landsat/TM imagery. The mosaic of Landsat/TM is used as the base image and all HJ-1/CCD images are automatically corrected through the image-to-image registration method. Converting the DN values of the HJ-1/CCD images to top of atmosphere (TOA) radiance with given calibration coefficients. Removing the atmospheric effects of remote-sensing images to obtain the surface reflectance. After the preprocessing has been done, all the HJ-1/CCD images within 1 month are subset and mosaicked; consequently, 10 mosaics for 10 months in the HRB are made and time series of the HRB mosaics from HJ-1/CCD are constructed.
dataset: The HJ-1/CCD remote-sensing data used in this research were provided by the China Centre for Resources Satellite Data and Application (CRESDA, http://www.cresda.com). The Landsat TM/ETM+ data were downloaded from the USGS website (http://landsat.usgs.gov/). The MODIS data were downloaded from the NASA Goddard Space Flight Center (http://ladsweb.nascom.nasa.gov/). The VHSR data were from Google Earth by Google Inc.
findings: The confusion matrix is used to evaluate the classification accuracy, showing an overall classification accuracy of over 90% in the HRB, which is quite higher than previous approaches. Furthermore, a ground campaign was performed to evaluate the accuracy of crop classification and an overall accuracy of 84.09% for the crop classification was achieved.

background: Long time series of land cover changes (LCCs) are critical in the analysis of long-term climate, environmental, and ecological changes. Although several moderate to fine resolution global land cover datasets have been publicly released and they show strong consistency at the global scale, they have large deviations at the regional scale; furthermore, high-quality land cover datasets from before 2000 are not available and the classification consistency among different datasets is not very good. Remote sensing has become widely used for global land cover mapping, as it can capture the changes of land cover quickly. Until now, several moderate to fine resolution global land cover datasets have been publicly released and the spatial resolutions of these products are between 1 km and 30 m. They show strong consistency at the global scale, but they have large deviations at the regional scale. The main problems include: (1) most of the land cover datasets have a relatively low resolution (500 m and lower) and their accuracies are usually lower than 75%; among the released datasets, GlobeLand30 and FROM-GLC30 have a spatial resolution of 30 m, and their overall accuracies are 80% and 72% respectively; (2) the classification accuracy of these released datasets at the regional scale is much lower than the claimed accuracy, especially at heterogeneous areas, which is difficult to meet the modeling requirements, and (3) all the datasets are after 2000 and do not have long time series and therefore cannot support the analysis of long-term climate, environmental, and ecological changes.
research objective: Therefore, by taking the advantages of the two categories of satellite data, we proposed a new time series land cover mapping method based on machine learning and it, thereafter, is applied to Heihe River Basin (HRB) for verification purposes.
challenges: Many comprehensive classification methods, such as GlobeLand30 using Landsat series satellite data have been developed but the ones with high accuracy usually require manual intervention; thus, more than 10 years’ land cover maps with areas over 140,000 km2 do not allow a lot of manual intervention. Although methods based on time series analysis like LCMM have the capability for making high-quality land cover datasets, a 16-day revisiting period of Landsat series satellite data does not support constructing time series data at HRB. Although machine learning methods, such as FROM-GLC30 have a lot of advantages and have been employed to map land cover using remote sensing imagery, they are usually limited by sampling amount and representativity; the requirement for consistency on data of these methods cannot be met by Landsat series satellite data.
methods: Firstly, the high-quality land cover datasets at HRB from 2011–2015, which were retrieved using the LCMM method, are used for quickly and accurately making training samples. Secondly, a strategy for transferring the training samples after 2011 to earlier years is established. Thirdly, the random forest model is employed to train the selected yearly samples and a land cover map for every year is subsequently made. Finally, comprehensive analysis and validation are carried out for evaluation.
dataset: Firstly, the high-quality land cover datasets at HRB from 2011–2015, which were retrieved using the LCMM method, are used for quickly and accurately making training samples.
findings: In this study, a long time series land cover dataset including 1986, 1990, 1995, 2000, 2005, 2010, 2011, 2012, 2013, 2014, and 2015 is finally made and an average precision of about 90% is achieved. It is the longest time series land cover map with 30 m resolution at HRB and the dataset has good time continuity and stability.

background: It is very difficult to have remote sensing data with both high spatial resolution and high temporal frequency; thus, two categories of land-use mapping methodology have been developed separately for coarser resolution and finer resolution data. Land use and land cover are the key factors for understanding the interactions between global changes and human activities, such as social, economic, and cultural activities. Moreover, it is one of the key parameters of land process modeling, and more accurate land use and land cover data will improve the accuracy of ecological, hydrological, and atmospheric models. Consequently, land use and land cover data are now widely used in many kinds of researches, such as biodiversity, carbon cycle, public health, crop yield estimation, urban sprawl, forest monitoring, and so on. Since land cover/use can be retrieved straightforwardly from remote sensing, many land cover/use mapping methods using remotely sensed data have been developed for the purposes of regional or global applications.
research objective: Therefore, by taking the spatiotemporal advantage of HJ-1/CCD data we propose a new method for finer resolution land cover mapping using the time series HJ-1/CCD data, which can greatly improve the land cover mapping accuracy.
challenges: This method uses much more data and dramatically increases the computation loading; the not very good geometric and radiometric qualities of HJ-1/CCD data lower its usability and increase the difficulty in its use.
methods: In our two study areas, the very high resolution remote sensing data within Google Earth are used to validate the land cover mapping results, which shows a very high mapping accuracy of 95.76% and 83.78% and a high Kappa coefficient of 0.9423 and 0.8165 in the Dahuofang area of Liaoning Province and the Heiquan area of Gansu Province respectively.
dataset: The HJ-1 satellite constellation consists of three satellites, named as HJ-1A, HJ-1B, and HJ-1C respectively. For CCD cameras, their nominal spatial resolution is 30 m. HJ-1/CCDs have three visible bands (430–520 nm, 520–600 nm, and 630–690 nm) and one near-infrared band (760–900 nm). The time series data are composed of one dataset per month, so this time series of data can depict the variation of typical land surface.
findings: The overall accuracy for classification result using the time series of HJ-1/CCD data is 96.76% and the Kappa coefficient is 0.9423; the corresponding overall accuracy and Kappa coefficient for classification result using single Hj-1/CCD data are 87.59% and 0.8296 respectively. Compared with the classification result from single Hj-1/CCD data, the overall accuracy of classification result using the time series HJ-1/CCD data is more than 10% and the Kappa coefficient is more than 0.1. The overall accuracy and Kappa coefficient of classification result using the time series HJ-1/CCD data are 83.78% and 0.8165 respectively; those using single HJ-1/CCD data are 70.82% and 0.665 respectively. It is similar to the comparison in the Dahuofang area that the overall accuracy of classification result using the time series HJ-1/CCD data is also 10% higher and Kappa coefficient is also 0.1 higher than that of classification result using single HJ-1/CCD data.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'land-cover datasets' in the context of eco-hydrological processes and earth system modeling?
Definition.Answer: Land-cover datasets refer to spatial data that represent the distribution of different types of land cover such as forests, croplands, grasslands, and urban areas. These datasets are crucial for eco-hydrological processes and earth system modeling as they provide baseline information for mapping and analyzing land cover changes using remote sensing technologies. They often involve categorizing continuous vegetation cover into discrete categories to support modeling requirements.

Definition.Question: What does 'classification accuracy' mean concerning land-cover datasets?
Definition.Answer: Classification accuracy in relation to land-cover datasets refers to the degree to which the dataset correctly identifies and categorizes different land cover types. It is often evaluated using a confusion matrix or through ground truthing methods. High classification accuracy is critical for ensuring that the dataset is reliable for modeling and research purposes, and it varies depending on the methods used and the quality of the remote sensing data.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods using Landsat series satellite data compare to those using HJ-1/CCD data in terms of classification accuracy and resolution for land-cover mapping?
Comparison.Answer: Landsat series satellite data are used in various land-cover mapping methods, presenting challenges such as lower resolution and difficulties in constructing time series data at regional scales. In contrast, HJ-1/CCD data, despite having issues with geometric and radiometric qualities, offer finer resolution and higher classification accuracy when used in time series compared to single data instances.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in classification challenges faced when using optical remotely sensed imagery in arid regions compared to heterogeneous areas?
Comparison.Answer: In arid regions, the highest uncertainty in classification occurs between categories like cropland and grassland due to thresholds for forest cover. In heterogeneous areas, the classification accuracy is much lower than claimed, especially with datasets at lower resolutions, complicating land-process modeling.

Comparison.Question: What similarities exist in the use of machine learning methods for land cover mapping in both Heihe River Basin and broader global applications?
Comparison.Answer: Machine learning methods, like those applied in the Heihe River Basin, are utilized globally for land cover mapping, benefiting from high-quality land cover datasets and offering high accuracy. Both applications face challenges such as the need for consistency and representative sampling, though they provide improved resolution and enable long-term series analysis.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges can arise when using remote sensing data for land cover classification, and how might these challenges affect the accuracy and usability of the resulting datasets?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges in using remote sensing data for land cover classification include high uncertainty in distinguishing between categories such as cropland and grassland, especially in arid regions. These challenges can lead to large uncertainties and errors in land-process modeling, affecting the accuracy and usability of datasets for eco-hydrological studies.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can time series analysis of data improve the consistency and accuracy of land cover datasets, and what might be the benefits of this approach for long-term environmental and ecological studies?
Interpretation.Answer: Time series analysis can improve the consistency and accuracy of land cover datasets by providing a more comprehensive understanding of land cover changes over time. This approach supports the development of high-quality datasets with good temporal continuity, which are beneficial for analyzing long-term environmental and ecological changes, contributing to more accurate modeling and predictions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the variability and uncertainty in land-cover classification when using remotely sensed imagery?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The variability and uncertainty in land-cover classification from optical remotely sensed imagery primarily arise due to differences in data quality, the lack of a standard approach for classifying continuous vegetation cover into discrete categories, and inconsistencies with Earth System Model requirements. High uncertainty is particularly noted between cropland and grassland categories and in dryland systems due to the minimum threshold required for forest cover.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why do high-quality land-cover datasets before 2000 have limited availability and inconsistency?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: High-quality land-cover datasets before 2000 are limited and inconsistent due to the absence of high-resolution data and the challenges in achieving classification consistency among different datasets. Additionally, most available datasets have relatively low resolution and their accuracies are significantly lower at regional scales, particularly in heterogeneous areas. This complicates the ability to support long-term climate, environmental, and ecological change analysis.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the computational load to increase significantly when using finer resolution data for land-cover mapping?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The computational load increases significantly when using finer resolution data for land-cover mapping because such methods involve processing a much larger volume of data, which demands more resources. Furthermore, the geometric and radiometric quality of the data, such as that from HJ-1/CCD, can be suboptimal, which adds to the complexity and difficulty in using the data effectively.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to develop a comprehensive method for mapping monthly land cover with fine spatial resolution and more categories of crop/vegetation?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to improve the accuracy of eco-hydrological and land-process modeling, particularly in arid regions like the Heihe River Basin (HRB), where current land-cover datasets cause significant uncertainty and modeling errors.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it necessary to use time series HJ-1/CCD data for finer resolution land cover mapping?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The intention is to leverage the spatiotemporal advantages of HJ-1/CCD data to significantly enhance land cover mapping accuracy, which is crucial for improving ecological, hydrological, and atmospheric modeling.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the instrumental steps involved in preprocessing remote sensing images to obtain surface reflectance for land cover classification?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To preprocess remote sensing images for obtaining surface reflectance, the steps include using a base image like Landsat/TM for image-to-image registration correction of HJ-1/CCD images, converting DN values to top of atmosphere (TOA) radiance using calibration coefficients, and removing atmospheric effects to obtain surface reflectance.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can multiple classifiers and multisource remotely sensed data be utilized to improve the accuracy of land cover mapping at fine spatial resolutions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Multiple classifiers and multisource remotely sensed data can be used by constructing mosaics from datasets like Landsat/TM and HJ-1/CCD, applying the image-to-image registration method, and processing data with varying spatio-temporal resolutions and spectral bands to map monthly land cover with more categories of crop/vegetation.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural approach is recommended for generating training samples for land cover datasets and transferring them across different time periods to ensure consistency in land cover mapping?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: A procedural approach involves using high-quality land cover datasets to quickly create training samples, establishing a strategy to transfer these samples to other time periods, employing a model like random forest to train yearly samples, and producing consistent land cover maps for each year.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the use of multisource remotely sensed data for high-resolution land cover mapping in arid regions?
Enablement.Answer: The use of platforms such as Google Earth Engine, which combines Landsat series data with powerful data processing capabilities, enables high-resolution land cover mapping by leveraging multisource remotely sensed data. This allows for effective change detection and classification in regions like the Heihe River Basin (HRB).

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of multiple classifiers enhance the accuracy of eco-hydrological and land-process modeling in complex ecosystems?
Enablement.Answer: Incorporating multiple classifiers with different spatio-temporal resolutions and spectral bands improves land cover mapping accuracy by addressing uncertainties in classification, particularly in complex ecosystems like the HRB, where discrepancies in vegetation types and cover thresholds pose challenges.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or methodologies enable the creation of long time series land cover datasets with high precision?
Enablement.Answer: The creation of long time series land cover datasets with high precision is enabled by using machine learning methods, such as the random forest model, which allows for robust training and classification of yearly samples. This approach, combined with strategies for transferring training samples across years, supports the development of consistent datasets with good time continuity and stability.

Expectation.Question: What challenges are expected when attempting to classify cropland and grassland categories using remotely sensed imagery?
Expectation.Answer: The highest uncertainty in land-cover classification from optical remotely sensed imagery occurs most frequently between the cropland and grassland categories due to differences in the minimum threshold required for forest cover. This challenge is exacerbated in arid regions where vegetation classification can be particularly difficult, leading to large uncertainties in classification results.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential limitations in using time series data from satellites like HJ-1/CCD for land-cover mapping in heterogeneous landscapes?
Judgmental.Answer: The potential limitations in using time series data from satellites like HJ-1/CCD for land-cover mapping in heterogeneous landscapes include increased computational demands due to large data volumes and the need for high geometric and radiometric quality. Despite these challenges, the use of time-series data has been shown to significantly improve mapping accuracy, as seen in studies achieving accuracies of over 95% in some areas. However, the usability of HJ-1/CCD data can be limited by its not very good geometric and radiometric qualities, which can affect classification accuracy in heterogeneous landscapes.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how remote sensing data can be effectively used to improve the accuracy of eco-hydrological models in arid regions.
Assertion.Answer: Remote sensing data can improve the accuracy of eco-hydrological models in arid regions by using multiple classifiers and multisource data with different spatio-temporal resolutions and spectral bands. These datasets can provide fine spatial resolution and more detailed categories of vegetation, addressing uncertainties in land-cover classification, especially in cropland and grassland categories.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the advantages of using time series data in land cover mapping methodologies.
Assertion.Answer: Time series data in land cover mapping methodologies allow for a more accurate depiction of land surface variations over time. This approach has been shown to significantly improve classification accuracies, as seen with HJ-1/CCD data, where the overall accuracy and Kappa coefficient were notably higher compared to single dataset usage.

Request/Directive.Question: Please provide an overview of data collection methods that enhance the accuracy of eco-hydrological modeling in river basins.
Request/Directive.Answer: Data collection methods that enhance eco-hydrological modeling accuracy in river basins involve using high-quality remote sensing data such as HJ-1/CCD and Landsat TM/ETM+ images. These images undergo preprocessing steps like radiometric correction and atmospheric effect removal to obtain surface reflectance. Time series mosaics are then created to improve classification accuracy. Furthermore, integrating data from multiple sources like MODIS and VHSR can provide comprehensive datasets to support accurate modeling.

Request/Directive.Question: Please discuss potential strategies for developing long time series land cover datasets with high spatial resolution and their application in environmental modeling.
Request/Directive.Answer: Developing long time series land cover datasets with high spatial resolution involves utilizing machine learning methods and satellite data like Landsat and HJ-1/CCD. A strategy includes using high-quality datasets from recent years to create training samples, transferring these samples to earlier years, and training models like random forests for annual land cover mapping. This approach can create datasets with good time continuity and stability, which are crucial for accurate environmental modeling and analysis of long-term climate and ecological changes.
